                                   _ANANDI RAMALINGAM
                                          ORDER

1. The Appellant filed an RTI application dated 22.10.2022 seeking information on the following points:

(i) Please provide with either hardcopy of soft copy of the inward and outward register maintained by the Department of Supervision, the Reserve Bank of India, Central office, Mumbai for the period starting from August 1. 2019, to October 30, 2019. (soft copy should provide the detail of unique reference number with details of both addresser and addressee).
(ii) Please provide with the copy all correspondence (including email exchanges) by the Department of Supervision, Reserve Bank of India to the 4 credit Page 1 of 9 information companies and credit institutions regarding sharing of customer data with Credit Information Companies for publishing and sharing of CIBIL scored reports for the period starting from August 1, 2019, to October 30, 2019.
(iii) Please provide with either hardcopy or softcopy of the inward and outward register maintained by the department of regulation, the Reserve Bank of India, Centra office, Mumbai for the period starting from August 1, 2019, to October 30,2019. (Soft copy should provide the details of unique reference Number with details of both addresser and addressee).
(iv) Please provide with the copy all correspondence (including email exchanges) by the Department of Regulation, Reserve Bank of India to the 4 credit information companies and credit institutions regarding sharing of customer data with credit information companies for publishing and sharing of CIBIL scored reports for the period starting from August 1, 2019, to October 30, 2019.

2. The CPIO replied vide letter dated 02.12.2022 and the same is reproduced as under:-

(i) Assuming that the applicant is seeking "Inward Outward Register" for the whole of the Department Supervision, Central Office, information sought is exempt under 8 (1)(g) and section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act, 2005, as it contains personal information. 
     (ii)     No such correspondence has been made by DoS.
     (iii)    Assuming that the applicant is seeking "Inward & Outward Register" for the
whole of the Department of Reglation, Central Office, information sought is exempt under 8(1)(g) and Section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act, 2005, as it contains personal information.
Page 2 of 9
(iv) It may be noted that 4 letters contain information relating to and/or supplied by third parties, as such notices under section 11(1) of RTI Act, 2005 have been issued to them. Further inputs in the matter will be provided in due course. If you desire to obtain hard copies of the other letters (after severing information exempt under section 8(1)(g) and Section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act,2005) vide which correspondences were made with the Credit Institutions relating to sharing of customer data with CICs for publishing and sharing of credit scored reports, you are advised to remit Rs. 274/- (Pages 137XRs.2/-) as photocopying charges payable under rule 4 of the Right to Information Rules, 2012, by way of Demand Draft/ Bankers Cheque / Postal order payable to Reserve Bank of India at Mumbai or in cash at any of our offices.

As regards the e - mails exchanged with CICs and Cis, it is stated that the collation and dissemination of this information in the form sough will disproportionately divert the resources of the bank in terms of section 7(9) of RTI Act, 2005."

3. Dissatisfied with the response received from the CPIO, the Appellant filed a First Appeal dated 16.12.2022 alleging that the information provided was incomplete, false and misleading. The FAA vide order dated 27.01.2023 directed to the CPIO to revisit point nos. (i), (iii) and (iv) of the RTI Application and provide a revised reply, as per the provisions of the RTI Act, within 10 working days from the date of receipt of this order. In compliance of the FAA's order, the CPIO replied vide letter dated 20.02.2023 and the same is reproduced as under:

"i. & iii. The inward register contains details (names and full addresses) of the senders of the letters received. The outward register contains details (names and full addresses) of the addressees of the letters sent. These are personal information, disclosure of which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the e Page 3 of 9 individuals and hence are exempt from disclosure under Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act, 2005.
The inward and outward registers contain details (Names, Designation and Employee IDs) of the employees involved in processing of the letters received (from the stage of inwarding till marking off from the register/portal). The disclosure of such information may endanger the physical safety of the person processing the case and is therefore exempt from disclosure under Section 8(1)(g) of the RTI Act, 2005.

iv. In continuation of inputs provided for the query vide our reply S5501/04.03.001/2022-23 dated November 29,2022, it may be noted as under, "In compliance with the Order passed by the Hon'ble First Appellate Authority, we advise that "query no. 4, relating to all the correspondence via email between DoR, RBI and 4 Credit Information Companies(CICs) and Credit Institutions(CIS) regarding sharing of customer data with CICs for publishing and sharing of CIBIL scored reports during the period between April 1, 2022 to November 30, 2022" is generic in nature. In this connection, it is stated that we are not maintaining any database which contains the list of all such e-mail correspondence with CICS/CIs. Thus, in order to collate the information, there is need to get the name of the officers who were then involved in the matter related to sharing of credit information and have to filter their emails in order to compile the information as sought in the RTI application. Accordingly, it would disproportionately divert the resources of the public authority. In this connection, a reference is invited to the judgment passedby the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the matter of "Central Board of Secondary Education & Anr. v. Aditya Bandopadhyay & Ors. (2011) 8 SCC 497), relevant part of which is as under.

"The nation does not want a scenario where 75% of the staff of public authorities spends 75% of their time in collecting and furnishing information to applicants instead of discharging their regular duties. The threat of penalties under the RTI Act and the pressure of the authorities under the RTI Act should not lead to employees of a public authorities prioritising information furnishing, at the cost of their normal and regular duties" In view of the above, provisions of section 7(9) of RTI Act, 2005 are getting attracted Page 4 of 9 for e-mails exchanged by DoR, RBI to the 4 CICs and CIs regarding sharing of customer data with CICs for publishing and sharing of CIBIL scored reports for the period starting from April 1, 2022 to November 30, 2022."

4. Aggrieved with the FAA's order, the Appellant approached the Commission with the instant Second Appeal dated 15.02.2023.

5. The appellant and on behalf of the respondent Shri Deepak Chikale, CPIO; Shri Honey Khosla, Law Officer and Shri Sidhant, Assistant General Manager, attended the hearing through video conference.

6. The appellant inter alia submitted that the exemptions invoked by the respondent were not applicable to the information sought by him by any stretch of imagination. He further argued that the FAA did not find it appropriate to comply with the principles of natural justice and to follow procedural laws that evolved upon good consensus while taking up the first appeal as a quasi-judicial authority. The appellant further submitted that the respondent had wrongly denied the information on hyper-technical grounds and non-disclosure of information on the ground that the records such as inward/outward registers contained names of individuals that could vitiate the principles of transparency and accountability that ought to be maintained by the public authorities.

7. The respondent while defending their case inter alia submitted that they had provided point-wise reply to the appellant vide letter dated 02.12.2022. Besides, they relied upon their written submissions dated 26.02.2024 and the relevant extracts thereof are reproduced as under:

"In the present second appeal, as regards query nos. 1 and 3, the appellant has contended that he is aggrieved by the non-disclosure of information as exemptions by no stretch of imagination could be evoked by the CPIO for denying the information. He has again contended that the reply given by the CPIO as regards query no. 2 is ambiguous. As regards the copy of letters provided in response to query no. 4, the appellant has questioned the exemption claimed under section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act. Regarding query no. 5, the appellant has contended that Page 5 of 9 complete report and other relevant material papers ought to have been provided by the CPIO. Further, the appellant has also claimed that he didn't receive any information as per the order passed by the FAA within 10 working days from the date of the order as directed by the FAA and the FAA had disposed- off the First Appeal without hearing the appellant in spite of a specific request for oral hearing.

8. It is humbly submitted that the order of the FAA was forwarded to the appellant vide letter dated February 07, 2023 wherein it was mentioned that the compliance as directed by the FAA would be provided in due course (copy enclosed and marked as Annexure- 'E'). Thereafter, vide letter dated February 20, 2023 (copy enclosed and marked as Annexure- 'F') the compliance of the order of the FAA was also forwarded to the appellant as Annex to the said letter. In the final compliance, as directed by the FAA, reasons for seeking exemption under section 8(1)(g) & (j) of the RTI Act were given stating that inward and outward registers contain details (names and full addresses) of the senders of the letters received and addressees of the letters sent and further the said registers contain details (names, designation and Employees IDs) of the employees involved in processing of the letters received (from the stage of inwarding till marking off from register/portal). As regards query no 4, it was stated that all correspondence via e-mail between DoR, RBI & four CICs and CIs regarding sharing of customer data with CICs for publishing and sharing of CIBIL scored reports during the period between April 1, 2022 to November 30, 2022 is generic in nature and database for this is not maintained which contains the list of all such e-mail correspondence with CICs/CIs. Thus, it was stated that in order to collate the information, there is need to get the name of the officers who were then involved in the matter relating to sharing of credit information and then to filter their emails in order to compile the information as sought in the RTI application. Accordingly, it has been informed that the same would disproportionately divert the resources of the public authority. Further, these mails would also contain certain information exempted under section 8 (1) of the RTI Act, 2005 and redaction of Page 6 of 9 such information would be a humongous process. The other contentions of the appellant in the present appeal have been dealt with by the FAA in its order dated January 24, 2023."

8. The Commission after adverting to the facts and circumstances of the case, hearing both parties and perusal of records, observes that the respondent replied to the appellant on 02.12.2022 and again on 20.02.2023, in compliance of the FAA's order. The Commission agrees with the respondent that the information sought by the appellant contained details (names and full addresses) of the senders of the letters received and addressees of the letters, details (names, designation and Employees IDs) of the employees involved in processing of the letters received (from the stage of inwarding till marking off from register/portal), details of customers in reports, etc. and seeking consent of third parties concerned in each of those cases was a voluminous process. Therefore, the respondent was not under an obligation to filter out information and records in the manner sought by the appellant in the RTI application. Therefore, the exemption claimed by the respondent was found sustainable in the eyes of law. Further, the Commission would like to draw the appellant's attention towards the observations of the Apex Court in respect of the conflict between right to information and right to privacy, highlighted in the judgment dated 26 September, 2018 in Justice K.S. Puttaswamy (Retd) vs Union Of India, reproduced hereunder:

"193. In Thalappalam Service Cooperative Bank Limited v State of Kerala 2013 (16) SCC 82 , this Court dealt with a conflict between the right to information [(protected by Article 19(1)(a)] and the right to privacy (protected by Article 21).

The Court observed:

"61. The right to information and right to privacy are, therefore, not absolute rights, both the rights, one of which falls under Article 19(1)(a) and the other under Article 21 of the Constitution of India, can obviously be regulated, restricted and curtailed in the larger public interest. Absolute or uncontrolled individual rights do not and cannot exist in any Page 7 of 9 modern State. Citizens' right to get information is statutorily recognised by the RTI Act, but at the same time limitations are also provided in the Act itself, which is discernible from the Preamble and other provisions of the Act."

The Court held that the balance between the right to information and the right to privacy is drawn under the Right to Information Act 2005: if the information which is sought is personal and has no relationship with a public activity or interest, a public authority is not legally bound to provide such information. If the information which is sought is to be made available in the larger public interest, reasons have to be recorded because the person from whom the information is sought has a right to privacy guaranteed by Article 21."

In view of the above, the Commission finds no infirmity with the reply given by the CPIO. Accordingly, the appeal is dismissed.

Copy of the decision be provided free of cost to the parties.

Sd/-
